input[type='submit'],button{-webkit-text-decoration:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:pointer;display:inline-block;--background-color__token-name:colors.interactive.base.light;background-color:rgba(224,224,224,1);text-align:center;-webkit-text-decoration:none;text-decoration:none;border:0;}/*!sc*/
input[type='submit']:hover,button:hover,input[type='submit']:focus,button:focus{-webkit-text-decoration:underline;text-decoration:underline;}/*!sc*/

          window.googletag = window.googletag || { cmd: [] }
        </script><script type="text/javascript">window.cns = window.cns || {}; window.cns.pageContext = {"channel":"fashion","content":{"copyCount":1516,"imageCount":197,"embedCount":134,"ratio":4.580060422960725,"midContentCadence":375},"contentType":"article","experiments":{},"keywords":{"copilotid":["654a6c1e46c1abd627b9c3f8"],"platform":["verso"],"tags":["fashion","spring-summer-2024","fashion-trends","shopping"]},"server":"production","slug":"spring-summer-2024-fashion-trends","subChannel":"fashion-trends","subSubChannel":"","templateType":"mt_commerce_article_two_column"};</script><link rel="preconnect" href="https://ads-static.conde.digital"/><script id="ads-v6" src="https://ads-static.conde.digital/production/cns/builds/vogue-uk/v6.js" async=""></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"The most talked-about collection at the spring/summer 2024 fashion shows was the one that wasn’t there. Phoebe Philo, yet to unveil the first fruits of her eponymous line, which had been originally slated to debut online in September some six years after she departed Céline, dominated the fashion news cycle throughout the month. As the spring/summer 2024 fashion trends piled up, designers waited nervously to see if their collections would be eclipsed by a spontaneous digital drop from a woman many revere as fashion’s messiah.\nRead more: See Every Vogue World 2024 Red Carpet Look From Paris\nHer cult status as industry saviour was only heightened by the news that the spring/summer 2024 show would be Sarah Burton’s last collection for Alexander McQueen, with Gabriela Hearst also departing Chloé. Incoming: Sabato de Sarno at Gucci, Peter Hawkings at Tom Ford, Peter Do at Helmut Lang, and Louise Trotter at Carven. Does fashion have a woman designer problem? At LVMH, the world’s largest luxury conglomerate, only Dior and Pucci have female creative directors, while Stella McCartney and Phoebe Philo are eponymously run. At Kering, the second biggest fashion conglomerate, not a single brand is helmed by a woman, nor a person of colour.\nSet against that demoralising disparity, and an equally sobering economic and political backdrop, designers played it safe for spring/summer 2024. The palette was muted, with black and white blotting out the colour-box brights that typically come to the fore for summer collections. Retina-searing red was one of the few tones that managed to make it through the muzzled colour wheel. The post-pandemic era of body positivity – and the nude looks that came with it – has largely faded, and with it the broader variety of body types that had begun to populate the runways.\nStatement gowns are out and discreet chic – buoyed up with wardrobe staples including trench coats, pencil skirts, trouser suits and good jeans – is in. At the fashion search engine Tagwalk, which scanned more than 11,000 images from the spring/summer 2024 shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris, looks that were tagged “minimalism” were up 46 per cent on the previous spring/summer 2023 season. Logo-tagged looks, meanwhile, were down 52 per cent, while ’90s-tagged looks were up 42 per cent – the latter was also the most searched tag. With the 25th anniversary of the untimely death of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy coming up, meanwhile, the Succession-fuelled “quiet luxury” trend is segueing into something that more closely resembles the understated ’90s-New-York elegance of the former Calvin Klein publicist.\nThe good news is that you probably already own most of this season’s key elements, and that clever styling – a splash of red here, a crisp white shirt there – serve as easy updates. Ballerinas and Mary-Janes are going nowhere, nor a well-cut blazer. And carrying a full-to-bursting bowling bag stuffed with last night’s high heels, a spare pair of socks, your notebook, wallet, keys and some paracetamol, is no longer anything to be ashamed of, thanks to Miuccia Prada and Miu Miu. The designer said her show was an exploration of modern beauty: “Not beauty, but beauties, an embracing of unique characters, the joy of life.” Momentarily, it gave us something to smile about.\n\nTop spring/summer 2024 buys:\n\nThe white dress: Free People Laine Midi-Dress, £268\nThe high-waisted trousers: Cos Wide-Leg Tailored Wool Trousers, £99\nThe polo top: Loewe Polo Sweater, £725\nThe transparent skirt: Prada Georgette Skirt, £1,000\nThe ’90s staple: Filippa K Long Tailored Skirt, £162\nThe modern flapper dress: Taller Marmo Cape-Effect Fringed Crepe Minidress, £995\nThe rose-printed piece: Rixo Bondi Silk Midi-Dress, £255\nThe short-shorts: Reformation Mason Tailored Shorts, £128\nThe metallic bag: Loewe Basket Bag (from eBay), £810\nThe boho dress: Marks & Spencer X Sienna Miller Dress, £89\n\n\nWhite noise\nWill you say yes to the white dress? Ranging from diaphanous and sheer to embroidered and densely-worked, designers signalled a clear shift away from the euphoric shots of colour and frothy pastels that come around every spring with a bevy of swan-white dresses.\nHigh-rise trousers\nTrust Jonathan Anderson to define the season’s silhouette. At Loewe, the designer celebrated his 10-year anniversary at the Spanish house by ushering in a new super-high-waisted trouser shape – so high, in fact, that the trousers came with an in-built corset to hold them in place under the bust. The good news: they’re an instant leg-lengthener, as Anderson’s contemporaries at Alaïa, Hermès, Louis Vuitton and Saint Laurent will attest.\nPolo club\nIf Mrs Prada says the polo shirt feels right again, who are we to disagree? With Miu Miu riding high as one of the most influential fashion shows on the calendar, prepare to see a lot more of the humble collared cotton style, which was styled with everything from men’s board shorts to ruffled micro-mini skirts, gold brocade shift dresses to sequin-embellished blouses. That country club mood persisted elsewhere, with rugby shirts making an appearance at Dries Van Noten and DSquared2, and flip-flops and spa towels accessorising looks at Chanel and The Row respectively. The key to making it feel effortless? Just remember to muss up your hair. No one likes a prim prepster.\nTransparent skirt\nAfter several seasons of sheer wafting gowns and lingerie-inspired details, the sheer skirt takes spring’s spotlight as a racy look to trial for day or night. Altuzarra lent it ladylike edge, pairing sheer pencil skirts with soft crew-neck sweaters and top-handle bags, a combination that showed up at Carolina Herrera, Coperni, Givenchy and Carven. If that feels a little frou-frou, double up sheer layers and style it with a bomber jacket and chunky belt, as seen at Louis Vuitton.\n’90s redux\nTime for a ’90s redux. As the world slides towards another recession, bold colours and ballsy logos are on the way out (Phoebe Philo’s October launch, with its uber-understated branding, made sure of that) and discreet chic is back. That the trend corresponds with the 25th anniversary of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy’s untimely death is no coincidence, as the New York Times recently pointed out. With a US presidential election and a potential Trump return on the horizon, cool-headed minimalism seems the only suitable sartorial riposte. Seek out camel pencil skirts, grey tailoring, white shirts and boyfriend-style jeans from the key practitioners: Proenza Schouler, Max Mara, Bottega Veneta, and Gucci.\nModern flapper\nEmbellished with Catherine wheels of crystals, metal fringing and shiny grommets, Prada’s spring proposition blended sculpted tailoring and shift dresses with Jazz Age pizzazz. The stand-out show christened a trend the Vogue editors are calling “the modern flapper”, traced through the season in the gilded fringing, shimmering headpieces and drop-waist dresses we associate with 1920s baby vamps, now remixed for 2024 with leather barn jackets and blazers.\nSmell the roses\nRomance was in the air at Simone Rocha, where fresh, pale pink, long-stemmed roses were trapped between layers of tulle that comprised the prettiest of party dresses. That rose theme curiously persisted across fashion’s four main cities for spring. Olivier Rousteing, feeling philosophical after most of his Balmain collection was stolen several days before his show, quoted Gertrude Stein’s 1913 poem ‘Sacred Emily’ with its famous line “Rose is a rose is a rose” ahead of a floral-bedecked outing; meanwhile Sarah Burton closed out her Alexander McQueen tenure with a collection partly inspired by a blood-red rose and female anatomy. Spanning rose prints, floral embellishment, three-dimensional appliqué, or petal-shaped silhouettes, designers from Rei Kawakubo to Richard Quinn are feeling, uh, thorny.\nShort shorts\nIf you can coolly observe the trend for short shorts without your mind immediately replaying that ‘1957’ song by the Royal Teens (or the Homer Simpson homage), well, you’re more culturally robust than we are. Micro shorts pumped down the catwalks in Milan – most memorably opening the new-look Gucci show, now under the direction of Sabato de Sarno – and filtered into Paris, too, at Chanel, Alexander McQueen and Isabel Marant. Think of it as the logical conclusion to autumn’s no-pants predilection.\nMetallics\nSequins, lamé and metallic treatments never seem to leave fashion’s trend orbit – but they gained renewed traction for spring as host city Paris looks ahead to the 2024 summer Olympics. A dose of supermodel sashay certainly helped too: at Ralph Lauren, Christy Turlington looked statuesque in a liquid gold gown, while at Versace, Claudia Schiffer lent chequerboard chainmail a sinuous ease.\nCraft\nMatthieu Blazy’s clever tricks continue at Bottega Veneta, where he moved on from denim-illusion leather to pom-pom adorned net dresses and fringed gowns that looked like they were made from feathers (they were, you guessed it, leather). The crafty illusions continued at Diesel, where Glenn Martens shredded deadstock denim and jersey into party dresses with a paint-peel effect and melted old movie posters into jackets. Elsewhere, crochet, embellishment and laser-cut leather extended the crafty mood.","isBasedOn":"https://www.vogue.co.uk/article/spring-summer-2024-fashion-trends","articleSection":"fashion","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Ellie Pithers","sameAs":"https://www.vogue.co.uk/profile/ellie-pithers"}],"dateModified":"2024-07-08T16:34:16.726+01:00","datePublished":"2023-11-09T10:22:18.327+00:00","headline":"The 10 Key Spring/Summer 2024 Fashion Trends To Know Now","image":["https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b493446c1abd627b9c48e/16:9/w_1920,h_1080,c_limit/ss24_trends_comp_.jpg","https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b493446c1abd627b9c48e/4:3/w_1704,h_1278,c_limit/ss24_trends_comp_.jpg","https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b493446c1abd627b9c48e/1:1/w_1280,h_1280,c_limit/ss24_trends_comp_.jpg"],"keywords":["fashion","spring/summer 2024","fashion trends","shopping","splitscreenimageleftinset","web"],"thumbnailUrl":"https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b493446c1abd627b9c48e/3:2/w_1920,h_1280,c_limit/ss24_trends_comp_.jpg","url":"https://www.vogue.co.uk/article/spring-summer-2024-fashion-trends","isPartOf":{"@type":"CreativeWork","name":"British Vogue"},"isAccessibleForFree":true,"alternativeHeadline":"British Vogue highlights the key spring/summer 2024 fashion trends to know now and how to wear them in 2024. class="ArticlePageChunksContent-etcMtP bwyLBj"><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageDisclaimerGrid-gIJgHl dJomLc grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="TextBlockWrapper-bNZsMC dqPNKv StyledTextblock-SJflO eYjtWF disclaimer ArticlePageDisclaimer-jNIoBl jmNNWn"><p class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ TextBlockText-gtrMkY iUEiRd egjflB kQegaj">We may earn a commission if you buy something from any affiliate links on our site.</p></div></div></div><div data-testid="ArticlePageChunks" class="ArticlePageChunks-fLyCVG eOdfIs"><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>The most talked-about collection at the spring/summer 2024 fashion shows was the one that wasn’t there. Phoebe Philo, yet to unveil the first fruits of her eponymous line, which had been originally slated to debut online in September some six years after she departed Céline, dominated the fashion news cycle throughout the month. As the spring/summer 2024 fashion trends piled up, designers waited nervously to see if their collections would be eclipsed by a spontaneous digital drop from a woman many revere as fashion’s messiah.</p><p><em>Read more: <a href="https://www.vogue.co.uk/gallery/vogue-world-red-carpet-2024">See Every Vogue World 2024 Red Carpet Look From Paris</a></em></p><p>Her cult status as industry saviour was only heightened by the news that the spring/summer 2024 show would be Sarah Burton’s last collection for Alexander McQueen, with Gabriela Hearst also departing Chloé. Incoming: Sabato de Sarno at Gucci, Peter Hawkings at Tom Ford, Peter Do at Helmut Lang, and Louise Trotter at Carven. Does fashion have a woman designer problem? At LVMH, the world’s largest luxury conglomerate, only Dior and Pucci have female creative directors, while Stella McCartney and Phoebe Philo are eponymously run. At Kering, the second biggest fashion conglomerate, not a single brand is helmed by a woman, nor a person of colour.</p><div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-iUTMTf jssHut consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><p>Set against that demoralising disparity, and an equally sobering economic and political backdrop, designers played it safe for spring/summer 2024. <a href="https://www.vogue.co.uk/article/colour-trends-ss24" target="_blank">The palette was muted</a>, with black and white blotting out the colour-box brights that typically come to the fore for summer collections. Retina-searing red was one of the few tones that managed to make it through the muzzled colour wheel. The post-pandemic era of body positivity – and the nude looks that came with it – has largely faded, and with it the broader variety of body types that had begun to populate the runways.</p><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--in-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--in-content" data-node-id="c9sqe8"></div></div><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed"><div data-testid="BylinesWrapper" class="BylinesWrapper-KIudk irTIfE bylines"><span class="BylineWrapper-jWHrLH hjnapm byline bylines__byline" data-testid="BylineWrapper" itemProp="author" itemType="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemProp="name" class="BylineNamesWrapper-jbHncj fuDQVo"><span data-testid="BylineName" class="BylineName-kwmrLn cYaBcc byline__name"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ BylinePreamble-iJolpQ iUEiRd fvctoH gnILss byline__preamble">By </span>Alexandra Macon</span></span></span></div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li class="AsideAdListItem-fTYGpp lmohmA hide-aside-ad"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ RecircMostPopularSummaryItem-jQxxiw kNiPPJ ad ad--aside"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--aside" data-node-id="yhpsg"></div></div></li></ul><div class="RecircMostPopularFooter-enPjgs knSlyA"></div></div></div></div><div class="StickyBoxPlaceholder-grPmrg dxAvXx"></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="tlind"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Statement gowns are out and discreet chic – buoyed up with wardrobe staples including <a href="https://www.vogue.co.uk/gallery/best-trench-coats">trench coats</a>, pencil skirts, trouser suits and good jeans – is in. At the fashion search engine Tagwalk, which scanned more than 11,000 images from the spring/summer 2024 shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris, looks that were tagged “minimalism” were up 46 per cent on the previous spring/summer 2023 season. Logo-tagged looks, meanwhile, were down 52 per cent, while ’90s-tagged looks were up 42 per cent – the latter was also the most searched tag. With the 25<sup>th</sup> anniversary of the untimely death of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy coming up, meanwhile, the <em>Succession</em>-fuelled “quiet luxury” trend is segueing into something that more closely resembles the understated ’90s-New-York elegance of the former Calvin Klein publicist.</p><div class="Container-hnJNtl gxMaIG"></div><p>The good news is that you probably already own most of this season’s key elements, and that clever styling – a splash of red here, a crisp white shirt there – serve as easy updates. Ballerinas and Mary-Janes are going nowhere, nor a well-cut blazer. And carrying a full-to-bursting bowling bag stuffed with last night’s high heels, a spare pair of socks, your notebook, wallet, keys and some paracetamol, is no longer anything to be ashamed of, thanks to Miuccia Prada and Miu Miu. The designer said her show was an exploration of modern beauty: “Not beauty, but beauties, an embracing of unique characters, the joy of life.” Momentarily, it gave us something to smile about.</p><hr/><div role="heading" aria-level="3" class="heading-h3">Top spring/summer 2024 buys:</div><ul><li><strong>The white dress:</strong> <a jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Will you say yes to the white dress? Ranging from diaphanous and sheer to embroidered and densely-worked, designers signalled a clear shift away from the euphoric shots of colour and frothy pastels that come around every spring with a bevy of swan-white dresses.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Valentino SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Valentino.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_120,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_240,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_320,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_640,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_960,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_1280,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b56f08005d04080cdea72/master/w_1600,c_limit/Valentino.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Valentino SS24.</p>

grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Trust Jonathan Anderson to define the season’s silhouette. At Loewe, the designer celebrated his 10-year anniversary at the Spanish house by ushering in a new super-high-waisted trouser shape – so high, in fact, that the trousers came with an in-built corset to hold them in place under the bust. The good news: they’re an instant leg-lengthener, as Anderson’s contemporaries at Alaïa, Hermès, Louis Vuitton and Saint Laurent will attest.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Rick Owens SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Rick%2520Owens.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_120,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_240,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_320,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_640,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_960,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_1280,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5d8e8005d04080cdea78/master/w_1600,c_limit/Rick%20Owens.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Rick Owens SS24.</p>

data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="whow4c"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>If Mrs Prada says the polo shirt feels right again, who are we to disagree? With Miu Miu riding high as one of the most influential fashion shows on the calendar, prepare to see a lot more of the humble collared cotton style, which was styled with everything from men’s board shorts to ruffled micro-mini skirts, gold brocade shift dresses to sequin-embellished blouses. That country club mood persisted elsewhere, with rugby shirts making an appearance at Dries Van Noten and DSquared2, and flip-flops and spa towels accessorising looks at Chanel and The Row respectively. The key to making it feel effortless? Just remember to muss up your hair. No one likes a prim prepster.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Victoria Beckham SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Victoria%2520Beckham.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_120,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_240,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_320,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_640,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_960,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_1280,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6286dbdfd4194bcc7761/master/w_1600,c_limit/Victoria%20Beckham.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Victoria Beckham SS24.</p>

data-testid="BylinesWrapper" class="BylinesWrapper-KIudk irTIfE bylines"><span class="BylineWrapper-jWHrLH hjnapm byline bylines__byline" data-testid="BylineWrapper" itemProp="author" data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="ohl21o"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>After several seasons of sheer wafting gowns and lingerie-inspired details, the sheer skirt takes spring’s spotlight as a racy look to trial for day or night. Altuzarra lent it ladylike edge, pairing sheer pencil skirts with soft crew-neck sweaters and top-handle bags, a combination that showed up at Carolina Herrera, Coperni, Givenchy and Carven. If that feels a little frou-frou, double up sheer layers and style it with a bomber jacket and chunky belt, as seen at Louis Vuitton.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Supriya Lele SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Supriya%2520Lele.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_120,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_240,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_320,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_640,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_960,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_1280,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b65138005d04080cdea9f/master/w_1600,c_limit/Supriya%20Lele.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Supriya Lele SS24.</p>

data-testid="BylinesWrapper" class="BylinesWrapper-KIudk irTIfE bylines"><span class="BylineWrapper-jWHrLH hjnapm byline bylines__byline" data-testid="BylineWrapper" itemProp="author" class="AsideAdListItem-fTYGpp lmohmA hide-aside-ad"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ RecircMostPopularSummaryItem-jQxxiw kNiPPJ ad ad--aside"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--aside" data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="87il7"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Time for a ’90s redux. As the world slides towards another recession, bold colours and ballsy logos are on the way out (Phoebe Philo’s October launch, with its uber-understated branding, made sure of that) and discreet chic is back. That the trend corresponds with the 25<sup>th</sup> anniversary of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy’s untimely death is no coincidence, as <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/24/style/carolyn-bessette-kennedy-fashion-influencer.html">the New York Times</a> recently pointed out. With a US presidential election and a potential Trump return on the horizon, cool-headed minimalism seems the only suitable sartorial riposte. Seek out camel pencil skirts, grey tailoring, white shirts and boyfriend-style jeans from the key practitioners: Proenza Schouler, Max Mara, Bottega Veneta, and Gucci.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Tove SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Tove.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_120,c_limit/Tove.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_240,c_limit/Tove.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_320,c_limit/Tove.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_640,c_limit/Tove.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_960,c_limit/Tove.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_1280,c_limit/Tove.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c850378c8d7e9281ce/master/w_1600,c_limit/Tove.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Tove SS24.</p>
</span></div></figure><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-2"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Tods SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_120,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_240,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_320,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_640,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_960,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_1280,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b75c846c1abd627b9c4f2/master/w_1600,c_limit/Tod&#x27;s.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Tod’s SS24.</p>

data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="xh0l0o"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Embellished with Catherine wheels of crystals, metal fringing and shiny grommets, Prada’s spring proposition blended sculpted tailoring and shift dresses with Jazz Age pizzazz. The stand-out show christened a trend the <em>Vogue</em> editors are calling “the modern flapper”, traced through the season in the gilded fringing, shimmering headpieces and drop-waist dresses we associate with 1920s baby vamps, now remixed for 2024 with leather barn jackets and blazers.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" class="SummaryItemBylineWrapper-boCfbi hYsZi summary-item__byline-date-icon"><div class="SummaryItemBaseByline-fFbXkY bNdTsY summary-item__byline"><div class="summary-item__byline__content"><div data-testid="BylinesWrapper" class="BylinesWrapper-KIudk irTIfE bylines"><span class="BylineWrapper-jWHrLH hjnapm byline bylines__byline" data-testid="BylineWrapper" itemProp="author" class="AsideAdListItem-fTYGpp lmohmA hide-aside-ad"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ RecircMostPopularSummaryItem-jQxxiw kNiPPJ ad ad--aside"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--aside" data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="c89t7d"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Romance was in the air at Simone Rocha, where fresh, pale pink, long-stemmed roses were trapped between layers of tulle that comprised the prettiest of party dresses. That rose theme curiously persisted across fashion’s four main cities for spring. Olivier Rousteing, feeling philosophical after most of his Balmain collection was stolen several days before his show, quoted Gertrude Stein’s 1913 poem ‘Sacred Emily’ with its famous line “Rose is a rose is a rose” ahead of a floral-bedecked outing; meanwhile Sarah Burton closed out her Alexander McQueen tenure with a collection partly inspired by a blood-red rose and female anatomy. Spanning rose prints, floral embellishment, three-dimensional appliqué, or petal-shaped silhouettes, designers from Rei Kawakubo to Richard Quinn are feeling, uh, thorny.</p><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Alexander McQueen SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Alexander%2520McQueen.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_120,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_240,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_320,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_640,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_960,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_1280,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b5f7050378c8d7e928191/master/w_1600,c_limit/Alexander%20McQueen.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Alexander McQueen SS24.</p>

class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="p58liee"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>If you can coolly observe the trend for short shorts without your mind immediately replaying that ‘1957’ song by the Royal Teens (or the Homer Simpson homage), well, you’re more culturally robust than we are. Micro shorts pumped down the catwalks in Milan – most memorably opening the new-look Gucci show, now under the direction of Sabato de Sarno – and filtered into Paris, too, at Chanel, Alexander McQueen and Isabel Marant. Think of it as the logical conclusion to autumn’s no-pants predilection.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Prada SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Prada.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_120,c_limit/Prada.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_240,c_limit/Prada.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_320,c_limit/Prada.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_640,c_limit/Prada.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_960,c_limit/Prada.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_1280,c_limit/Prada.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654a75392508617a8c20322c/master/w_1600,c_limit/Prada.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Prada SS24.</p>

class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="vih71"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Sequins, lamé and metallic treatments never seem to leave fashion’s trend orbit – but they gained renewed traction for spring as host city Paris looks ahead to the 2024 summer Olympics. A dose of supermodel sashay certainly helped too: at Ralph Lauren, Christy Turlington looked statuesque in a liquid gold gown, while at Versace, Claudia Schiffer lent chequerboard chainmail a sinuous ease.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-bPWknp CIRNj callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed callout--group-item callout--group-item-1"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Schiaparelli SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_120,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_240,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_320,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_640,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_960,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_1280,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6928dbdfd4194bcc7782/master/w_1600,c_limit/Schiaparelli.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Schiaparelli SS24.</p>

data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="2y0489"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa jvNNFa body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Matthieu Blazy’s clever tricks continue at Bottega Veneta, where he moved on from denim-illusion leather to pom-pom adorned net dresses and fringed gowns that looked like they were made from feathers (they were, you guessed it, leather). The crafty illusions continued at Diesel, where Glenn Martens shredded deadstock denim and jersey into party dresses with a paint-peel effect and melted old movie posters into jackets. Elsewhere, crochet, embellishment and laser-cut leather extended the crafty mood.</p><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-eVDQiB byBkf asset-embed"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-eJxoAx dBHGoQ asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-umhxW kGxnNB responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-cWuUZO dUOtEa AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-cXBNxi eCxVQK asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Bottega Veneta SS24." class="ResponsiveImageContainer-eybHBd fptoWY responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/Bottega%2520Veneta.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_120,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_240,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_320,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_640,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_960,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_1280,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/654b6ef68005d04080cdeac0/master/w_1600,c_limit/Bottega%20Veneta.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-jSZdqE kohprp caption AssetEmbedCaption-fNQBPI fmQnYP asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ CaptionText-bHjzlu iUEiRd qICFz iXWezO caption__text"><p>Bottega Veneta SS24.</p>

REACH"}],"venuePage.venueContactName":[{"type":0,"value":"Contact"}]},"consentEnabled":true,"brandIdentityAssets":{"favicon":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Fverso\u002Fstatic\u002Fvogue\u002Fassets\u002Ffavicon.ico","signInModalAsset":{"default":{"altText":"Sign In","sources":{"sm":{"url":"\u002Fverso\u002Fstatic\u002Fvogue\u002Fassets\u002Fsign-in-modal.png"}}},"crosswords":{"altText":"Sign In","sources":{"sm":{"url":"\u002Fverso\u002Fstatic\u002Fvogue\u002Fassets\u002Fsign-in-modal-crosswords.png"}}},"voting":{"altText":"Sign In","sources":{"sm":{"url":"\u002Fverso\u002Fstatic\u002Fvogue\u002Fassets\u002Fsign-in-modal-voting.png"}}}}},"useTrailingSlash":false,"globalMessage":null,"fastly":{"response":{"headers":{"model-name":"article","modified-at":1720452843,"surrogate-control":"stale-while-revalidate=60, stale-if-error=86400, max-age=14400"}}},"google":{"isSwgEnabledOnTenantChannel":false,"isSwgEnabledOnSystem":false,"registrationSourceCode":"","swgPublicationId":"","swgSku":"","entitlement":{"processEntitlementResponse":false}},"head.canonicalUrl":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Farticle\u002Fspring-summer-2024-fashion-trends","head.hreflang":[{"lang":"zh-Hant","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.com.tw\u002Farticle\u002F2024-spring-summer-fashion-trends"},{"lang":"en-GB","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Farticle\u002Fspring-summer-2024-fashion-trends"}],"head.description":"British Vogue highlights the key spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends to know now and how to wear them in 2024. From metallics to the new prep, these are the standout spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends from the runway collections.","head.keywords":"fashion,spring\u002Fsummer 2024,fashion trends,shopping","head.og.type":"article","head.robots":"index, follow, noarchive, max-image-preview:large","head.title":"The 10 Key Spring\u002FSummer 2024 Fashion Trends To Know Now | British Vogue","tenant":"vogue-uk","head.social.title":"The 10 Key Spring\u002FSummer 2024 Trends To Know Now","head.social.description":"British Vogue brings the lowdown on the standout spring\u002Fsummer 2024 trends and how to wear them now.","head.promo.dek":"British Vogue highlights the key spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends to know now and how to wear them in 2024. From metallics to the new prep, these are the standout spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends from the runway collections.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"The most talked-about collection at the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion shows was the one that wasn’t there. Phoebe Philo, yet to unveil the first fruits of her eponymous line, which had been originally slated to debut online in September some six years after she departed Céline, dominated the fashion news cycle throughout the month. As the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends piled up, designers waited nervously to see if their collections would be eclipsed by a spontaneous digital drop from a woman many revere as fashion’s messiah.\nRead more: See Every Vogue World 2024 Red Carpet Look From Paris\nHer cult status as industry saviour was only heightened by the news that the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 show would be Sarah Burton’s last collection for Alexander McQueen, with Gabriela Hearst also departing Chloé. Incoming: Sabato de Sarno at Gucci, Peter Hawkings at Tom Ford, Peter Do at Helmut Lang, and Louise Trotter at Carven. Does fashion have a woman designer problem? At LVMH, the world’s largest luxury conglomerate, only Dior and Pucci have female creative directors, while Stella McCartney and Phoebe Philo are eponymously run. At Kering, the second biggest fashion conglomerate, not a single brand is helmed by a woman, nor a person of colour.\nSet against that demoralising disparity, and an equally sobering economic and political backdrop, designers played it safe for spring\u002Fsummer 2024. The palette was muted, with black and white blotting out the colour-box brights that typically come to the fore for summer collections. Retina-searing red was one of the few tones that managed to make it through the muzzled colour wheel. The post-pandemic era of body positivity – and the nude looks that came with it – has largely faded, and with it the broader variety of body types that had begun to populate the runways.\nStatement gowns are out and discreet chic – buoyed up with wardrobe staples including trench coats, pencil skirts, trouser suits and good jeans – is in. At the fashion search engine Tagwalk, which scanned more than 11,000 images from the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris, looks that were tagged “minimalism” were up 46 per cent on the previous spring\u002Fsummer 2023 season. Logo-tagged looks, meanwhile, were down 52 per cent, while ’90s-tagged looks were up 42 per cent – the latter was also the most searched tag. With the 25th anniversary of the untimely death of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy coming up, meanwhile, the Succession-fuelled “quiet luxury” trend is segueing into something that more closely resembles the understated ’90s-New-York elegance of the former Calvin Klein publicist.\nThe good news is that you probably already own most of this season’s key elements, and that clever styling – a splash of red here, a crisp white shirt there – serve as easy updates. Ballerinas and Mary-Janes are going nowhere, nor a well-cut blazer. And carrying a full-to-bursting bowling bag stuffed with last night’s high heels, a spare pair of socks, your notebook, wallet, keys and some paracetamol, is no longer anything to be ashamed of, thanks to Miuccia Prada and Miu Miu. The designer said her show was an exploration of modern beauty: “Not beauty, but beauties, an embracing of unique characters, the joy of life.” Momentarily, it gave us something to smile about.\n\nTop spring\u002Fsummer 2024 buys:\n\nThe white dress: Free People Laine Midi-Dress, £268\nThe high-waisted trousers: Cos Wide-Leg Tailored Wool Trousers, £99\nThe polo top: Loewe Polo Sweater, £725\nThe transparent skirt: Prada Georgette Skirt, £1,000\nThe ’90s staple: Filippa K Long Tailored Skirt, £162\nThe modern flapper dress: Taller Marmo Cape-Effect Fringed Crepe Minidress, £995\nThe rose-printed piece: Rixo Bondi Silk Midi-Dress, £255\nThe short-shorts: Reformation Mason Tailored Shorts, £128\nThe metallic bag: Loewe Basket Bag (from eBay), £810\nThe boho dress: Marks & Spencer X Sienna Miller Dress, £89\n\n\nWhite noise\nWill you say yes to the white dress? Ranging from diaphanous and sheer to embroidered and densely-worked, designers signalled a clear shift away from the euphoric shots of colour and frothy pastels that come around every spring with a bevy of swan-white dresses.\nHigh-rise trousers\nTrust Jonathan Anderson to define the season’s silhouette. At Loewe, the designer celebrated his 10-year anniversary at the Spanish house by ushering in a new super-high-waisted trouser shape – so high, in fact, that the trousers came with an in-built corset to hold them in place under the bust. The good news: they’re an instant leg-lengthener, as Anderson’s contemporaries at Alaïa, Hermès, Louis Vuitton and Saint Laurent will attest.\nPolo club\nIf Mrs Prada says the polo shirt feels right again, who are we to disagree? With Miu Miu riding high as one of the most influential fashion shows on the calendar, prepare to see a lot more of the humble collared cotton style, which was styled with everything from men’s board shorts to ruffled micro-mini skirts, gold brocade shift dresses to sequin-embellished blouses. That country club mood persisted elsewhere, with rugby shirts making an appearance at Dries Van Noten and DSquared2, and flip-flops and spa towels accessorising looks at Chanel and The Row respectively. The key to making it feel effortless? Just remember to muss up your hair. No one likes a prim prepster.\nTransparent skirt\nAfter several seasons of sheer wafting gowns and lingerie-inspired details, the sheer skirt takes spring’s spotlight as a racy look to trial for day or night. Altuzarra lent it ladylike edge, pairing sheer pencil skirts with soft crew-neck sweaters and top-handle bags, a combination that showed up at Carolina Herrera, Coperni, Givenchy and Carven. If that feels a little frou-frou, double up sheer layers and style it with a bomber jacket and chunky belt, as seen at Louis Vuitton.\n’90s redux\nTime for a ’90s redux. As the world slides towards another recession, bold colours and ballsy logos are on the way out (Phoebe Philo’s October launch, with its uber-understated branding, made sure of that) and discreet chic is back. That the trend corresponds with the 25th anniversary of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy’s untimely death is no coincidence, as the New York Times recently pointed out. With a US presidential election and a potential Trump return on the horizon, cool-headed minimalism seems the only suitable sartorial riposte. Seek out camel pencil skirts, grey tailoring, white shirts and boyfriend-style jeans from the key practitioners: Proenza Schouler, Max Mara, Bottega Veneta, and Gucci.\nModern flapper\nEmbellished with Catherine wheels of crystals, metal fringing and shiny grommets, Prada’s spring proposition blended sculpted tailoring and shift dresses with Jazz Age pizzazz. The stand-out show christened a trend the Vogue editors are calling “the modern flapper”, traced through the season in the gilded fringing, shimmering headpieces and drop-waist dresses we associate with 1920s baby vamps, now remixed for 2024 with leather barn jackets and blazers.\nSmell the roses\nRomance was in the air at Simone Rocha, where fresh, pale pink, long-stemmed roses were trapped between layers of tulle that comprised the prettiest of party dresses. That rose theme curiously persisted across fashion’s four main cities for spring. Olivier Rousteing, feeling philosophical after most of his Balmain collection was stolen several days before his show, quoted Gertrude Stein’s 1913 poem ‘Sacred Emily’ with its famous line “Rose is a rose is a rose” ahead of a floral-bedecked outing; meanwhile Sarah Burton closed out her Alexander McQueen tenure with a collection partly inspired by a blood-red rose and female anatomy. Spanning rose prints, floral embellishment, three-dimensional appliqué, or petal-shaped silhouettes, designers from Rei Kawakubo to Richard Quinn are feeling, uh, thorny.\nShort shorts\nIf you can coolly observe the trend for short shorts without your mind immediately replaying that ‘1957’ song by the Royal Teens (or the Homer Simpson homage), well, you’re more culturally robust than we are. Micro shorts pumped down the catwalks in Milan – most memorably opening the new-look Gucci show, now under the direction of Sabato de Sarno – and filtered into Paris, too, at Chanel, Alexander McQueen and Isabel Marant. Think of it as the logical conclusion to autumn’s no-pants predilection.\nMetallics\nSequins, lamé and metallic treatments never seem to leave fashion’s trend orbit – but they gained renewed traction for spring as host city Paris looks ahead to the 2024 summer Olympics. A dose of supermodel sashay certainly helped too: at Ralph Lauren, Christy Turlington looked statuesque in a liquid gold gown, while at Versace, Claudia Schiffer lent chequerboard chainmail a sinuous ease.\nCraft\nMatthieu Blazy’s clever tricks continue at Bottega Veneta, where he moved on from denim-illusion leather to pom-pom adorned net dresses and fringed gowns that looked like they were made from feathers (they were, you guessed it, leather). The crafty illusions continued at Diesel, where Glenn Martens shredded deadstock denim and jersey into party dresses with a paint-peel effect and melted old movie posters into jackets. Elsewhere, crochet, embellishment and laser-cut leather extended the crafty mood.","isBasedOn":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Farticle\u002Fspring-summer-2024-fashion-trends","articleSection":"fashion","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Ellie Pithers","sameAs":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Fprofile\u002Fellie-pithers"}],"dateModified":"2024-07-08T16:34:16.726+01:00","datePublished":"2023-11-09T10:22:18.327+00:00","headline":"The 10 Key Spring\u002FSummer 2024 Fashion Trends To Know Now","image":["https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.vogue.co.uk\u002Fphotos\u002F654b493446c1abd627b9c48e\u002F16:9\u002Fw_1920,h_1080,c_limit\u002Fss24_trends_comp_.jpg","https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.vogue.co.uk\u002Fphotos\u002F654b493446c1abd627b9c48e\u002F4:3\u002Fw_1704,h_1278,c_limit\u002Fss24_trends_comp_.jpg","https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.vogue.co.uk\u002Fphotos\u002F654b493446c1abd627b9c48e\u002F1:1\u002Fw_1280,h_1280,c_limit\u002Fss24_trends_comp_.jpg"],"keywords":["fashion","spring\u002Fsummer 2024","fashion trends","shopping","splitscreenimageleftinset","web"],"thumbnailUrl":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.vogue.co.uk\u002Fphotos\u002F654b493446c1abd627b9c48e\u002F3:2\u002Fw_1920,h_1280,c_limit\u002Fss24_trends_comp_.jpg","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Farticle\u002Fspring-summer-2024-fashion-trends","isPartOf":{"@type":"CreativeWork","name":"British Vogue"},"isAccessibleForFree":true,"alternativeHeadline":"British Vogue highlights the key spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends to know now and how to wear them in 2024. most talked-about collection at the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion shows was the one that wasn’t there. Phoebe Philo, yet to unveil the first fruits of her eponymous line, which had been originally slated to debut online in September some six years after she departed Céline, dominated the fashion news cycle throughout the month. As the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 fashion trends piled up, designers waited nervously to see if their collections would be eclipsed by a spontaneous digital drop from a woman many revere as fashion’s messiah."],["p",["em","Read more: ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Fgallery\u002Fvogue-world-red-carpet-2024","isExternal":false},"See Every Vogue World 2024 Red Carpet Look From Paris"]]],["p","Her cult status as industry saviour was only heightened by the news that the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 show would be Sarah Burton’s last collection for Alexander McQueen, with Gabriela Hearst also departing Chloé. Incoming: Sabato de Sarno at Gucci, Peter Hawkings at Tom Ford, Peter Do at Helmut Lang, and Louise Trotter at Carven. Does fashion have a woman designer problem? At LVMH, the world’s largest luxury conglomerate, only Dior and Pucci have female creative directors, while Stella McCartney and Phoebe Philo are eponymously run. At Kering, the second biggest fashion conglomerate, not a single brand is helmed by a woman, nor a person of colour."],["cm-unit"],["p","Set against that demoralising disparity, and an equally sobering economic and political backdrop, designers played it safe for spring\u002Fsummer 2024. ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Farticle\u002Fcolour-trends-ss24","target":"_blank","isExternal":false},"The palette was muted"],", with black and white blotting out the colour-box brights that typically come to the fore for summer collections. Retina-searing red was one of the few tones that managed to make it through the muzzled colour wheel. The post-pandemic era of body positivity – and the nude looks that came with it – has largely faded, and with it the broader variety of body types that had begun to populate the runways."],["native-ad",{"position":"in-content","shouldDisplayLabel":true}],["inline-embed",{"props":{"dangerousCaption":"","dangerousCredit":"","image":{"id":"654b9eef8005d04080cdeb03","altText":"The 1600w","height":1067}}}},"level":"block","ref":"654b9eef8005d04080cdeb03","type":"image"}],["ad",{"position":"mid-content"}],["p","Statement gowns are out and discreet chic – buoyed up with wardrobe staples including ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Fgallery\u002Fbest-trench-coats","isExternal":false},"trench coats"],", pencil skirts, trouser suits and good jeans – is in. At the fashion search engine Tagwalk, which scanned more than 11,000 images from the spring\u002Fsummer 2024 shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris, looks that were tagged “minimalism” were up 46 per cent on the previous spring\u002Fsummer 2023 season. Logo-tagged looks, meanwhile, were down 52 per cent, while ’90s-tagged looks were up 42 per cent – the latter was also the most searched tag. With the 25",["sup","th"]," anniversary of the untimely death of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy coming up, meanwhile, the ",["em","Succession"],"-fuelled “quiet luxury” trend is segueing into something that more closely resembles the understated ’90s-New-York elegance of the former Calvin Klein publicist."],["inline-embed",{"type":"cneinterlude","props":{"brand":"vogue-uk","embeddedVideos":[],"hasExcludedEmbed":false,"playerBase":"https:\u002F\u002Fplayer.cnevids.com","isRailEligible":false,"isRightRail":false,"relatedVideo":{"showRelatedVideo":false,"brand":"vogue-uk","related":null,"pageSize":4}}}],["p","The good news is that you probably already own most of this season’s key elements, and that clever styling – a splash of red here, a crisp white shirt there – serve as easy updates. Ballerinas and Mary-Janes are going nowhere, nor a well-cut blazer. And carrying a full-to-bursting bowling bag stuffed with last night’s high heels, a spare pair of socks, your notebook, wallet, keys and some paracetamol, is no longer anything to be ashamed of, thanks to Miuccia Prada and Miu Miu. The designer said her show was an exploration of modern beauty: “Not beauty, but beauties, an embracing of unique characters, the joy of life.” Momentarily, it gave us something to smile disagree? With Miu Miu riding high as one of the most influential fashion shows on the calendar, prepare to see a lot more of the humble collared cotton style, which was styled with everything from men’s board shorts to ruffled micro-mini skirts, gold brocade shift dresses to sequin-embellished blouses. That country club mood persisted elsewhere, with rugby shirts making an appearance at Dries Van Noten and DSquared2, and flip-flops and spa towels accessorising looks at Chanel and The Row respectively. The key to making it feel effortless? Just remember to muss up your hair. No one likes a prim 1600w","height":1067}}}},"level":"block","ref":"654bad1a240795294f78e556","type":"image"}],["ad",{"position":"mid-content"}],["p","Time for a ’90s redux. As the world slides towards another recession, bold colours and ballsy logos are on the way out (Phoebe Philo’s October launch, with its uber-understated branding, made sure of that) and discreet chic is back. That the trend corresponds with the 25",["sup","th"]," anniversary of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy’s untimely death is no coincidence, as ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F10\u002F24\u002Fstyle\u002Fcarolyn-bessette-kennedy-fashion-influencer.html","isExternal":false},"the New York Times"]," recently pointed out. With a US presidential election and a potential Trump return on the horizon, cool-headed minimalism seems the only suitable sartorial riposte. Seek out camel pencil skirts, grey tailoring, white shirts and boyfriend-style jeans from the key practitioners: Proenza Schouler, Max Mara, Bottega Veneta, and long-stemmed roses were trapped between layers of tulle that comprised the prettiest of party dresses. That rose theme curiously persisted across fashion’s four main cities for spring. Olivier Rousteing, feeling philosophical after most of his Balmain collection was stolen several days before his show, quoted Gertrude Stein’s 1913 poem ‘Sacred Emily’ with its famous line “Rose is a rose is a rose” ahead of a floral-bedecked outing; meanwhile Sarah Burton closed out her Alexander McQueen tenure with a collection partly inspired by a blood-red rose and female anatomy. Spanning rose prints, floral embellishment, three-dimensional appliqué, or petal-shaped silhouettes, designers from Rei Kawakubo to Richard Quinn are feeling, uh, mind immediately replaying that ‘1957’ song by the Royal Teens (or the Homer Simpson homage), well, you’re more culturally robust than we are. Micro shorts pumped down the catwalks in Milan – most memorably opening the new-look Gucci show, now under the direction of Sabato de Sarno – and filtered into Paris, too, at Chanel, Alexander McQueen and Isabel Marant. Think of it as the logical conclusion to autumn’s no-pants
